questions.text: A previously healthy 60-year-old man comes to the physician because of progressively worsening shortness of breath for the past 2 months. He does not experience shortness of breath at rest. He also occasionally has a dry cough. He has not had fever, chills, or night sweats. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 40 years. He drinks a beer daily and occasionally more on weekends. He does not use illicit drugs. He is 183 cm (6 ft 0 in) tall and weighs 66 kg (145 lbs); BMI is 19 kg/m2. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 94/min, respirations are 21/min, and blood pressure is 136/88 mm Hg. Lung auscultation reveals a prolonged expiratory phase and end-expiratory wheezing. Spirometry shows an FEV1:FVC ratio of 62% after bronchodilator inhalation, an FEV1 of 60% of predicted, and a total lung capacity of 125% of predicted. The diffusion capacity of the lung (DLCO) is decreased. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Interstitial lung disease (ILD) results in progressively worsening shortness of breath, a dry cough, decreased FEV1, and decreased DLCO. Smoking is also a risk factor for ILD and weight loss can occasionally occur. However, ILD results in restrictive lung disease; the TLC would therefore be decreased, and FEV1/FVC would be normal or increased. Moreover, patients with ILD typically have bibasilar inspiratory crackles on auscultation rather than end-expiratory wheezing.

B) INCORRECT:

Subacute hypersensitivity pneumonitis can result in dyspnea that worsens over the course of 2 months, a dry cough, weight loss, decreased FEV1, and decreased DLCO. However, subacute hypersensitivity pneumonitis typically results in restrictive (or mixed restrictive/obstructive) lung disease; total lung capacity would therefore be reduced. Moreover, patients with hypersensitivity pneumonitis typically have bibasilar inspiratory crackles on auscultation rather than wheezing and a history of occupational exposure to an allergen (e.g., animal proteins, mold).

C) CORRECT:

Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) manifests with progressively worsening dyspnea, end-expiratory wheezing, a prolonged expiratory phase, and spirometry findings of a decreased FEV1/FVC ratio, a decreased FEV1, and increased TLC (due to increased lung compliance). Smoking is responsible for over 90% of cases of COPD. Emphysema-predominant COPD can manifest with cachexia (due to increased work of breathing) and an occasional dry cough. Decreased DLCO levels indicate a decreased surface area for air exchange from the destruction of the alveoli present in emphysema.

The patient has an FEV1 between 50 and 80% of the predicted value, which means he has moderate COPD (GOLD class 2) and should therefore be treated with inhaled long-acting beta-2 agonists such as salmeterol or formoterol. Patients with COPD should receive the pneumococcal vaccine every 5–6 years and the influenza vaccine annually, and should also be counseled on smoking cessation.

D) INCORRECT:

Bronchiectasis can result in progressively worsening dyspnea, cough, wheezing, weight loss, and features of obstructive lung disease (e.g., ↓ FEV1:FVC ratio). However, patients with bronchiectasis would have a productive cough with thick, foul-smelling sputum (due to anaerobic infection) and coarse inspiratory crackles on auscultation.

E) INCORRECT:

Bronchial asthma would result in breathlessness, cough, wheezing, decreased FEV1, and decreased FEV1/FVC. The TLC may also be increased in some patients. However, bronchial asthma is typically characterized by acute exacerbations, in contrast to this patient's 2 months of progressive dyspnea. Moreover, weight loss would not be expected, and DLCO would be normal or mildly increased.
questions.hint: This patient has decreased FEV1 (< 80% of predicted value), decreased FEV1:FVC (< 70%), and increased total lung capacity (TLC) (> 120% of predicted). A chest x-ray of patients with this diagnosis often shows hyperlucency of the lung fields and bilateral diaphragmatic flattening.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. He has had increasing shortness of breath and a productive cough for the past year. He can walk up a flight of stairs without stopping. He has hypertension and his only medication is amlodipine. He has a history of asthma during childhood. He used to work at a shipyard and retired 5 years ago. He smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years but quit 16 years ago. His pulse is 98/min, respirations are 25/min and blood pressure is 134/88 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 93%. Scattered expiratory wheezing and rhonchi are heard throughout both lung fields. Cardiac examination shows no murmurs, rubs, or gallops. Spirometry shows an FEV1:FVC ratio of 63% and an FEV1 of 65% of predicted. His diffusing capacity for carbon monoxide (DLCO) is 40% of predicted. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although this patient's respiratory symptoms and spirometry findings may suggest asthma, his DLCO is reduced rather than normal or elevated as would be expected in asthma patients. Furthermore, his symptoms have progressed for the span of over one year and do not occur in the form of acute asthma attacks.

One of the reasons why DLCO may be elevated in patients with asthma is a better ventilation-perfusion matching due to increased perfusion in the lung apices.

B) INCORRECT:

Chronic bronchitis is an important differential diagnosis in patients with a history of smoking. This patient group usually presents with (exertional) dyspnea, productive cough, and end-expiratory wheezes lasting for at least 3 months in 2 consecutive years. Spirometry also shows an obstructive lung pattern. However, DLCO is typically normal in patients with chronic bronchitis, in contrast to the decreased levels seen in this patient, since there are no structural changes in alveoli that impair the diffusing capacity.

C) INCORRECT:

While patients with CHF may present with dyspnea due to pulmonary edema, they usually have additional signs and symptoms of left-sided (e.g., S3/S4 gallop, cool extremities, cerebral and renal dysfunction, diaphoresis) or right-sided (e.g., peripheral pitting edema, jugular venous distention, hepatomegaly, ascites) heart failure. Moreover, CHF would rather show a restrictive respiratory pattern in pulmonary functioning tests as a result of pulmonary edema.

D) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary hypertension is often asymptomatic in the early stages, but may manifest with dyspnea and coughing. Diffusion capacity is also often impaired in individuals with pulmonary hypertension. Although spirometry may show an obstructive lung pattern, e.g. when COPD is the underlying cause, it usually shows normal findings in patients with pulmonary hypertension. Also, physical examination would typically show a loud and palpable second heart sound, jugular vein distention and/or other symptoms of right heart failure.

E) INCORRECT:

Individuals with bronchiectasis typically present with dyspnea, wheezing, and productive cough. If bronchiectasis is caused by an obstructive pulmonary disease (e.g., COPD), spirometry may show a similar pattern. Diffusion capacity may also be impaired depending on the pulmonary condition involved, but is not typically affected in individuals with bronchiectasis. Moreover, the absence of other typical features of bronchiectasis, such as production of large amounts of sputum, hemoptysis, and recurrent pulmonary infections makes a different cause more likely.

F) CORRECT:

This patient's age, symptoms (dyspnea, productive cough, expiratory wheezing), and history of asthma and tobacco use in combination with signs of airway obstruction on pulmonary function test are highly suggestive of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). COPD can manifest with emphysema from the destruction of alveolar walls due to respiratory obstruction and recurrent infections. Decreased DLCO is a typical finding of emphysema that reflects the reduction of gas exchange due to a loss of diffusion area.

Nonsmokers and individuals < 50 years of age who present with COPD and emphysema should be tested for alpha-1-antitrypsin deficiency.

G) INCORRECT:

This patient presents with typical features of asbestosis including dyspnea, coughing, wheezing on auscultation, and reduction of diffusion capacity. Although his history of shipyard work is a risk factor for asbestosis, this condition would typically manifest with a restrictive pattern in pulmonary functioning test (normal or decreased FEV1, normal or increased FEV1:FVC) making a different diagnosis more likely.
questions.hint: An FEV1:FVC ratio of < 70% and a reduced FEV1  < 80% on spirometry indicate an obstructive lung pathology. This patient also has a decreased DLCO (N = 80–120%).

questions.text:
A 26-year-old man comes to his physician because he has started to experience shortness of breath with exertion. He does not have shortness of breath at rest. He has also had lower back pain for the past year. He describes the pain as an aching stiffness that improves with movement. He has not had fever, cough, rhinorrhea, or weight loss. Medical history is otherwise unremarkable and he takes no routine medications. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows tenderness over the sacroiliac joints bilaterally. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. X-rays of the spine and pelvis show bilateral sacroiliac joint erosions and spinal syndesmophytes. This patient is most likely to develop which of the following sets of findings on pulmonary function testing?



Lung compliance
FEV1

FVC
Residual volume (RV)
DLCO




A
Increased
decreased
decreased
increased
decreased


B
Normal
decreased
decreased
increased
normal


C
Normal
decreased
decreased
normal
normal


D
Decreased
normal
decreased
decreased
increased
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Features of obstructive lung disease (decreased FEV1, decreased FVC, increased RV) combined with increased lung compliance and decreased DLCO are seen in patients with severe emphysema. Ankylosing spondylitis is associated with restrictive lung disease.

B) INCORRECT:

Features of obstructive lung disease (decreased FEV1, decreased FVC, increased RV) combined with normal lung compliance and normal DLCO are seen in patients with chronic bronchitis. Ankylosing spondylitis is associated with restrictive lung disease.

C) CORRECT:

Individuals with ankylosing spondylitis often develop restrictive lung disease either secondary to decreased mobility of the thoracic spine and costovertebral joints or interstitial lung disease. Restrictive lung disease manifests with normal or decreased FEV1 and decreased FVC. Patients with disease secondary to extrapulmonary conditions present with normal lung compliance (no changes in the elastic properties of lung tissue or in surface tension), normal residual volume (no changes in lung parenchyma), and normal DLCO (no change in alveolar surface area). Patients with disease due to parenchymal conditions present with decreased lung compliance (fibrotic lung parenchyma compromises the lung's ability to distend), decreased residual volume (enhanced elastic recoil decreases pulmonary volumes) and decreased DLCO (alveolar-capillary membrane thickens and compromises diffusion).

D) INCORRECT:

Normal FEV1 with decreased FVC, decreased RV, and decreased lung compliance is typically seen in patients with restrictive lung disease due to an intraparenchymal pathology (e.g., interstitial lung disease). Although restrictive lung disease secondary to interstitial disease can be seen in ankylosing spondylitis, patients with interstitial lung disease have a decreased rather than increased DLCO..
questions.hint: This young man presents with progressive shortness of breath, lower back pain that improves with movement, and x-ray findings of sacroiliac joint erosions and spinal syndesmophytes, which suggests ankylosing spondylitis.

questions.text:
A 47-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of a cough productive of frothy, light yellow sputum and worsening breathlessness. The cough used to occur only in the mornings but is now present throughout the entire day. One year ago, she had a similar episode of cough lasting 4–5 months but did not seek medical treatment. She has not had fever, night sweats, hemoptysis, or weight loss. She has hypercholesterolemia. She has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for the past 30 years. Her only medication is simvastatin. She is 168 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 89 kg (196 lb); BMI is 32 kg/m2. Her temperature is 36.7°C (98°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 23/min, and blood pressure is 134/78 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 92%. Scattered expiratory wheezing and rhonchi are heard throughout both lung fields. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. A CT scan of the chest discloses thickening of the walls of large and small airways and no evidence of alveolar septal destruction. Pulmonary function testing is most likely to show which of the following sets of findings?



FEV1

FEV1/FVC
DLCO

RV



A
Decreased
decreased
normal
increased


B
Decreased
normal
increased
normal


C
Decreased
normal
decreased
decreased


D
Normal
normal
increased
normal


E
Decreased
decreased
increased
increased


F
Decreased
decreased
decreased
increased


G
Normal
normal
decreased
normal


H
Decreased
normal
normal
normal
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

A productive cough for ≥ 3 months each year for ≥ 2 consecutive years is consistent with chronic bronchitis, a clinical form of COPD. Patients with COPD have a decreased FEV1 and a decreased FEV1/FVC ratio due to an increase in airway resistance. In chronic bronchitis, the increase in airway resistance is caused by the thickening of large and/or small airways. In emphysema, small airway collapse during the expiratory phase is responsible for increased airway resistance. Air trapping can occur in patients with COPD, leading to an increased residual volume. In patients with chronic bronchitis, air trapping occurs if small airway disease is present. An important feature that distinguishes chronic bronchitis from emphysema is a normal DLCO since chronic bronchitis, unlike emphysema, is not associated with alveolar destruction.

It is important to note that clearly distinguishing between emphysema and chronic bronchitis via clinical features (pink puffers vs. blue bloaters) may not always be possible because most patients with COPD have a combination of emphysema and chronic bronchitis.

See “Pulmonary function testing findings in obstructive vs. restrictive lung diseases” table.

B) INCORRECT:

Decreased FEV1, normal FEV1/FVC, normal residual volume, and increased DLCO has been reported in patients with obesity. A different constellation of findings is expected in this patient with COPD.

C) INCORRECT:

Decreased FEV1, normal FEV1/FVC, decreased DLCO, and decreased residual volume can be seen in patients with intrinsic restrictive lung disease, which is caused by conditions such as interstitial lung disease, pneumonia, and pulmonary edema. These conditions typically present with inspiratory crackles and cause different findings on chest imaging (e.g., honeycombing of the lung parenchyma, fluid in the alveolar space). Moreover, pneumonia typically has an acute course and would result in other symptoms, such as fever and malaise.

D) INCORRECT:

Increased DLCO with normal FEV1, FEV1/FVC, and residual volume can be seen in patients with polycythemia. A different constellation of findings would be expected in a patient with chronic COPD.

E) INCORRECT:

Increased DLCO and increased residual volume with decreased FEV1 and FEV1/FVC are typically seen in bronchial asthma, which can present with cough, breathlessness, and wheezing. However, bronchial asthma is characterized by reversible small airway obstruction and does not result in thickening of the large airways. Moreover, this patient's history of smoking and a productive cough make COPD more likely.

F) INCORRECT:

Decreased DLCO and increased residual volume with decreased FEV1 and FEV1/FVC can be seen in emphysema-predominant COPD, which can cause breathlessness, cough, and an expiratory wheeze on auscultation. However, in emphysema, a chest CT would show evidence of alveolar septal destruction. Moreover, in patients with emphysema-predominant COPD, the onset of dyspnea usually precedes the onset of cough, and only scant expectorate is produced. Patients are usually cachectic and have a barrel-shaped, hyperinflated chest with hyperresonance on percussion.

G) INCORRECT:

Decreased DLCO with normal FEV1, FEV1/FVC, and residual volume can be seen in patients with pulmonary vascular disease (e.g., pulmonary embolism, pulmonary hypertension), severe anemia, and carboxyhemoglobinemia (e.g., smokers, CO poisoning). Although this patient is a smoker, the presence of COPD would result in a different constellation of findings.

H) INCORRECT:

Decreased FEV1 with normal FEV1/FVC, DLCO, and residual volume can be seen in patients with extrinsic restrictive lung disease due to respiratory muscle weakness (e.g., myasthenia gravis, Guillain-Barré syndrome, amyotrophic lateral sclerosis) or severe chest wall deformities (e.g., kyphoscoliosis, ankylosing spondylitis). A different constellation of findings would be expected in a patient with COPD.
questions.hint: This patient has a significant smoking history as well as clinical features and imaging findings that are consistent with a form of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).

questions.text: A previously healthy 64-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a dry cough and progressively worsening shortness of breath for the past 2 months. She has not had fever, chills, or night sweats. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 45 years. She appears thin. Examination of the lung shows a prolonged expiratory phase and end-expiratory wheezing. Spirometry shows decreased FEV1:FVC ratio (< 70% predicted), decreased FEV1, and a total lung capacity of 125% of predicted. The diffusion capacity of the lung (DLCO) is decreased. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Bronchial asthma would result in breathlessness, cough, wheezing, decreased FEV1, and decreased FEV1/FVC. However, bronchial asthma is typically characterized by acute exacerbations, in contrast to this patient's 2 months of progressive dyspnea. Moreover, weight loss would not be expected, and DLCO would be normal or mildly increased.

B) INCORRECT:

Bronchiectasis can result in progressively worsening dyspnea, cough, wheezing, weight loss, and features of obstructive lung disease (e.g., ↓ FEV1:FVC ratio). However, patients with bronchiectasis would have a productive cough with thick, foul-smelling sputum (due to anaerobic infection) and coarse inspiratory crackles on auscultation.

C) INCORRECT:

Subacute hypersensitivity pneumonitis can result in dyspnea that worsens over the course of 2 months, a dry cough, weight loss, in decreased FEV1 and decreased DLCO. However, subacute hypersensitivity pneumonitis typically results in restrictive (or mixed restrictive/obstructive) lung disease; forced vital capacity would therefore be reduced. Moreover, patients with hypersensitivity pneumonitis typically have bibasilar inspiratory crackles on auscultation rather than wheezing and a history of occupational exposure to an allergen (e.g., animal proteins, mold).

D) INCORRECT:

Interstitial lung disease (ILD) results in progressively worsening shortness of breath, a dry cough, decreased FEV1, and decreased DLCO. Smoking is a risk factor for ILD and weight loss can occur occasionally. However, ILD results in restrictive lung disease (decreased TLC and normal or increased FEV1/FVC). Moreover, patients with ILD typically have bibasilar inspiratory crackles on auscultation rather than wheezing.

E) CORRECT:

Smoking causes over 90% of cases of COPD, which results in decreased FEV1/FVC, decreased FEV1, and increased TLC (due to increased lung compliance). This patient is thin and has progressively worsening dyspnea, an end-expiratory wheeze, and a dry cough, which most likely indicates emphysema-predominant COPD. In emphysema, destruction of the alveoli results in a decreased surface area for air exchange; DLCO levels are therefore decreased.
questions.hint: This patient has decreased FEV1, decreased FEV1:FVC ratio, and increased total lung capacity (TLC). An X-ray of the chest would most likely show increased lucency of the lung fields and bilateral flattening of the diaphragm.

questions.text: During a clinical study examining the diffusion of gas between the alveolar compartment and the pulmonary capillary blood, men between the ages of 20 and 50 years are evaluated while they hold a sitting position. After inhaling a water-soluble gas that rapidly combines with hemoglobin, the concentration of the gas in the participant's exhaled air is measured and the diffusion capacity is calculated. Assuming that the concentration of the inhaled gas remains the same, which of the following is most likely to increase the flow of the gas across the alveolar membrane?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Changes in the kinetic energy of a gas affect its diffusion capacity. Higher temperatures increase kinetic energy, while colder temperatures decrease it. A cold chamber thus decreases the rate of diffusion across the alveolar membrane. Cold air also induces bronchoconstriction, further reducing the volume of gas reaching the alveolar membrane.

B) INCORRECT:

Diffusion capacity changes during the inhalation-exhalation cycle as a result of changing surface area. The increased volume during inhalation increases the available surface area and thus also the diffusion rate, while the decreased volume during deep exhalation decreases the diffusion capacity.

C) INCORRECT:

Blood flow to the lungs is affected by gravity. Lying supine results in a uniform distribution of blood throughout the lungs, permitting optimal diffusion in the upper lobes at the same rate as the lower lobes. In contrast, standing permits optimal diffusion only in the lower lobes, decreasing overall alveolar perfusion and subsequently reducing diffusion capacity.

D) INCORRECT:

The Valsalva maneuver increases pleural pressure, decreasing the pressure gradient across the alveolar barrier. This decreases the diffusion of the gas across the alveolar membrane.

E) CORRECT:

The diffusion capacity of the lung for carbon monoxide (DLCO) is determined by the carbon monoxide transfer coefficient and total alveolar volume. Exercise increases total alveolar volume (the surface area available for gas diffusion) by recruiting additional lung zones not used during at-rest respiration. This process results in increased capillary recruitment and leads to increased pulmonary capillary blood volume, nearby doubling DLCO. . This effect is magnified with exercise intensity. Other factors that increase pulmonary blood volume and DLCO include supine position, pregnancy, and obesity.

The destruction of alveolar walls in emphysema greatly reduces the surface area available for gas exchange in the lungs, significantly lowering diffusion capacity.

F) INCORRECT:

Hunching over results in a small level of atelectasis and a reduced diffusion surface area. Thus, it decreases (not increases) the rate of diffusion for this gas across the alveolar membrane. Patients with a severe kyphosis have reduced diffusion capacity via the same mechanism.
questions.hint: The rate of diffusion of gas, in this case, carbon monoxide, through the alveolar/capillary interface is governed by Fick’s law of diffusion. This law states that the volume of gas per unit time (Vgas) moving across the alveolar-capillary barrier is directly proportional to the surface area of the barrier (A), the diffusion coefficient (D), and the difference in concentration between the two sides (P1-P2), but is inversely proportional to the barrier thickness (T), such that: Vgas = [A x D x (P1-P2)] / T.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 10-month history of progressive shortness of breath and a cough productive of a small amount of white phlegm. Bilateral end-expiratory wheezing is heard on auscultation of the chest. Pulmonary function tests show total lung capacity that is 108% of predicted, an FEV1 that is 56% of predicted, and an FEV1:FVC ratio of 62%. Which of the following interventions is most likely to slow the decline in FEV1 in individuals with this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

COPD is a preventable lung disease characterized by airway obstruction due to inflammation of the small airways and is primarily caused by long-term smoking. Smoking cessation is the single most important measure to slow the decline in lung function at all stages of COPD. It has been shown that the earlier the cessation is achieved, the greater the benefit for lung function. Other measures that improve lung function of COPD patients include treatment with inhaled corticosteroids and bronchodilators.

B) INCORRECT:

Physiotherapy with breathing exercises as part of pulmonary rehabilitation is a supportive measure in the treatment of COPD patients. It has been shown to improve symptoms, exercise capacity, and quality of life. However, there is an intervention with a greater impact on the rate of decline in FEV1..

C) INCORRECT:

Salmeterol is a long-acting beta agonist used as combination or monotherapy in patients with COPD. This drug has been shown to significantly decrease exacerbation rates and improve lung function. However, there is an intervention with a greater impact on the rate of decline in FEV1..

D) INCORRECT:

Fluticasone is an inhaled corticosteroid used in combination with a long-acting bronchodilator in patients with severe COPD. Even though this combination therapy has been shown to improve lung function and exacerbations rates, fluticasone monotherapy seems to have little impact on the rate of decline in FEV1..

E) INCORRECT:

Intravenous alpha-1 antitrypsin (AAT) replacement therapy is used in patients with COPD due to severe AAT deficiency, a genetic disorder presenting with liver disease as well as early-onset panacinar emphysema. However, severe AAT deficiency is rare and would usually manifest earlier in life with hepatic involvement (e.g., hepatitis, cirrhosis, hepatocellular carcinoma).
questions.hint: This patient's history of dyspnea and productive cough combined with a decreased FEV1, decreased FEV1:FVC ratio, and increased total lung capacity make chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) the most likely diagnosis.

questions.text:
A 63-year-old woman comes to the physician because of worsening shortness of breath and recurrent pulmonary infections over the past 3 years. She has smoked 2 packs of cigarettes daily for the past 35 years. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 92%. Examination shows scattered expiratory wheezing and rhonchi bilaterally. X-rays of the chest are shown. Pulmonary function testing is most likely to show which of the following sets of findings?



FEV1

FEV1/FVC
TLC
RV



A
Decreased
decreased
increased
increased


B
Decreased
increased
decreased
decreased


C
Normal
normal
normal
normal


D
Decreased
decreased
normal
increased


E
Decreased
normal
decreased
normal
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Chronic inflammation of the airways due to inhaled toxins (smoking) leads to progressive destruction of lung parenchyma distal to the terminal bronchioles. Abnormal, permanent dilation of the air spaces (emphysema) caused by loss of elastic tissue and air trapping behind collapsed or obstructed bronchioles increases residual volume (RV) and total lung capacity (TLC). Narrowing of the airways, which is seen in patients with COPD, increases the resistance to air flow and consequently decreases forced expiratory volume (FEV1) and the Tiffeneau-Pinelli index (FEV1/FVC). Damage to the alveolar walls furthermore results in decreased DLCO because the surface area for gaseous exchange is diminished.

B) INCORRECT:

This set of findings is consistent with restrictive lung disease (e.g., due to interstitial lung disease). All lung volumes and capacities are equally decreased as a result of the lungs' impaired ability to expand (↓ compliance). The FEV1/FVC ratio is typically increased (> 80%), because FVC approaches FEV1 as a result of higher lung elasticity. Patients with restrictive lung disease usually present with dyspnea and decreased oxygen saturation, both of which are seen here. However, an x-ray would show reticular opacities as a sign of fibrosis and bibasilar inspiratory crackles or rales would be heard on auscultation. Although smoking is a risk factor for idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis, it is more commonly associated with obstructive lung disease.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (PA view) of a patient with history of amiodarone pulmonary toxicity

A coarse reticular pattern from pulmonary fibrosis is present diffusely in both lungs. Additional ill-defined opacities represent areas of consolidation, which would typically appear as high-attenuation lesions on CT.

Although a necklace is seen on the radiograph, jewelry is usually removed prior to imaging.

C) INCORRECT:

Normal spirometric findings in a patient with shortness of breath and decreased oxygen saturation indicate an extrapulmonary cause of hypoxia (e.g., anemia or cardiovascular disease). However, this patient's x-ray and auscultatory findings are consistent with advanced chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, which manifests with characteristic changes in pulmonary function testing.

D) INCORRECT:

This set of findings is consistent with asthma. Decreased FEV1 and FEV1/FVC ratio indicate an increased airway resistance due to bronchial obstruction, while the residual volume (RV) is elevated due to air trapping. Total lung capacity (TLC) is typically normal in patients with asthma. Acute asthma manifests with dyspnea, wheezing, and decreased oxygen saturation, all of which are seen here. In severe cases, x-ray findings can show hyperinflation and a flattened diaphragm. However, asthma is an episodic disease, and symptoms typically occur after exposure to a trigger factor. This patient's history of smoking and slowly progressive dyspnea is consistent with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, which manifests with different changes in pulmonary function testing.
Image Description:

Chest x-ray (PA view)

Large lung volumes (green outline and arrows) are accompanied by intercostal space widening (examples indicated by red arrows) and diaphragmatic flattening, indicating hyperinflation.

E) INCORRECT:

This set of findings is consistent with a restrictive pulmonary disorder caused by respiratory muscle weakness (e.g., due to neuromuscular disease). FEV1, forced vital capacity (FVC), and total lung capacity (TLC) are decreased equally because of insufficient inspiration (resulting in a normal FEV1/FVC ratio). The residual volume (RV) is typically not affected. Weakened respiratory muscles can manifest with dyspnea, recurrent pulmonary infections, and, in severe cases, decreased oxygen saturation. However, while a chest x-ray might show an elevated diaphragm or atelectasis, it would not show hyperinflation or a flattened diaphragm. Moreover, rales might be heard on auscultation but usually not wheezing.
questions.hint: Together with a significant smoking history, this patient's symptoms and x-ray findings (hyperinflation, flattened diaphragm, increased sagittal thoracic diameter) are consistent with emphysema, a key component of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of progressively worsening shortness of breath on exertion. He is concerned that he has asthma and would like to be started on albuterol. Which of the following findings is most suggestive of a diagnosis other than asthma?

choices.text: Bipyramidal crystals measuring 50 μm on sputum analysis
Reid index of 0.34 on endobronchial biopsy
129% of the predicted diffusion capacity of the lung for carbon monoxide
Decrease in systolic blood pressure by 16 mm Hg during inspiration
Decrease in FEV1 by 6% after administration of high-dose methacholine

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Bipyramidal structures measuring 50 μm on sputum analysis are consistent with Charcot-Leyden crystals. Charcot-Leyden crystals and Curschmann spirals are sputum findings that are associated with bronchial asthma.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of lung tissue (H&E stain)

Lumen of a bronchus filled with mucous and inflammatory exudate.
A bipyramidal hexagonal structure (yellow overlay) is visible in the center of the image.

This structure is known as a Charcot-Leyden crystal, a histopathologic finding in patients with eosinophilic inflammation and/or proliferation (e.g., asthma, parasitic infections).

B) INCORRECT:

An inspiratory:expiratory ratio (I:E ratio) of 1:3 on auscultation indicates a prolongation of the expiratory phase (normally 1:2) and is consistent with obstructive lung diseases such as asthma.

C) INCORRECT:

A Reid index of 0.34 on endobronchial biopsy is considered to be below normal limits (normally about 0.4). The Reid index compares the thickness of mucus-secreting glands with the thickness of the wall between epithelium and cartilage in the bronchial tree. A Reid index ≥ 0.5 would be associated with chronic bronchitis, which can present with features of bronchial asthma (e.g., episodic dyspnea, wheezing), but a Reid index ≤ 0.4 is associated with bronchial asthma (due to hyperplasia and hypertrophy of smooth muscle).

D) INCORRECT:

The normal diffusion capacity of the lung for carbon monoxide (DLCO) 80–120% of the predicted value. Testing 129% of DLCO can be seen in cases of patients with bronchial asthma, as well as obesity, polycythemia, and left-to-right shunts.

E) INCORRECT:

A decrease in systolic blood pressure > 10 mm Hg during inspiration is called pulsus paradoxus and occurs in conditions such as cardiac tamponade, obstructive sleep apnea, pericarditis, and croup, but it is also seen in bronchial asthma.

F) CORRECT:

A > 20% reduction in FEV1 from baseline following the administration of high-dose methacholine, an inhaled bronchoconstrictor, indicates airway hyperresponsiveness (positive bronchoprovocation test). Airway hyperresponsiveness is present even in the late stages of bronchial asthma, when airway obstruction becomes partially irreversible due to airway remodeling. A decrease of < 20% in FEV1 after the administration of high-dose methacholine effectively rules out bronchial asthma.
questions.hint: Bronchial asthma is characterized by airway hyperresponsiveness.

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-week history of a dry cough. She does not smoke or use illicit drugs. Physical examination shows mild conjunctival hyperemia. Chest auscultation shows fine crackles in both lung fields. Laboratory studies show a total calcium concentration of 10.8 mg/dL. The results of spirometry are shown (dashed loop shows normal for comparison). Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show an increase in which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Increased levels of monoclonal IgG are seen in multiple myeloma, which can cause hypercalcemia. However, myeloma affects the bone marrow and manifests with bone pain, pathological fractures, or features of anemia (e.g., pallor, fatigue). Lung involvement in myeloma is extremely rare. This patient most likely has sarcoidosis, which is associated with elevated IgG levels in about 50% of cases, but these are not monoclonal antibodies.

B) INCORRECT:

Increased levels of parathyroid hormone-related protein (PTHrP) cause hypercalcemia. A common cause of PTHrP secretion is squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) of the lung, which is an important differential diagnosis in this patient given her cough. However, SCC of the lung typically occurs among smokers and it does not explain the bilateral crackles, conjunctival hyperemia, or spirometric findings of restrictive lung disease. This patient most likely has sarcoidosis, in which hypercalcemia is caused by increased 1-alpha hydroxylase activity rather than PTHrP secretion.

C) INCORRECT:

Mast cell tryptase is typically elevated in asthma, which can manifest with a dry cough. Individuals with allergic bronchial asthma often also have allergic conjunctivitis, which causes conjunctival hyperemia. However, asthma typically causes wheezes rather than fine crackles, and the flow-volume loop would show a shift to the left with decreased expiratory airflow (obstructive lung disease). Moreover, asthma does not explain the hypercalcemia in this patient.
Image Description:

Patients with an obstructive lung disease typically have a concave flow-volume loop (middle) compared to healthy patients (left).
Emphysema typically causes a “scooped out” curve (right) due to the collapse of small airways during expiration.

D) INCORRECT:

Neutrophil elastase activity is typically elevated in smokers and individuals with alpha-1 antitrypsin (ATT) deficiency. Both ATT deficiency and smoking are risk factors for emphysema, which can cause a dry cough. However, the flow-volume loop of patients with emphysema would show a shift to the left with decreased expiratory airflow (obstructive lung disease) and scalloping of the expiratory flow curve. Moreover, emphysema does not explain the hypercalcemia seen in this patient.
Image Description:

Patients with an obstructive lung disease typically have a concave flow-volume loop (middle) compared to healthy patients (left).
Emphysema typically causes a “scooped out” curve (right) due to the collapse of small airways during expiration.

E) CORRECT:

Sarcoidosis is a condition that causes noncaseating granulomatous inflammation. The epithelioid cells of pulmonary granulomas produce angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) and increased ACE activity is a possible finding in patients with sarcoidosis. Hypercalcemia in sarcoidosis is the result of increased 1-alpha hydroxylase activity in the activated pulmonary macrophages. Patients with sarcoidosis can also develop polyclonal hypergammaglobulinemia. Another finding associated with sarcoidosis is an increased CD4+:CD8+ cell ratio in bronchoalveolar lavage. This finding can be used to differentiate sarcoidosis from hypersensitivity pneumonitis, which is associated with a low CD4+:CD8+ cell ratio.

F) INCORRECT:

Cold agglutinin titers are elevated following Mycoplasma pneumonia, which manifests with a dry subacute cough, fine crackles, and features of restrictive lung disease on spirometry. Conjunctivitis is also a common extrapulmonary manifestation of Mycoplasma pneumonia. However, Mycoplasma pneumonia does not explain the hypercalcemia in this patient.
questions.hint: The flow-volume loop shows a shift to the right and a decrease in total lung volume with a relative sparing of airflow during expiration. These features are consistent with restrictive lung disease (RLD). The constellation of a dry cough, hypercalcemia, and spirometric findings of RLD is consistent with sarcoidosis. Patients with sarcoidosis may develop conjunctival hyperemia due to conjunctivitis, uveitis, or scleritis.

questions.text: A 49-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of a dry cough and shortness of breath on exertion. She also reports recurrent episodes of pain, stiffness, and swelling in her wrist and her left knee over the past 6 months. She had two miscarriages at age 24 and 28. Physical examination shows pallor, ulcerations on the palate, and annular hyperpigmented plaques on the arms and neck. Fine inspiratory crackles are heard over bilateral lower lung fields on auscultation. Which of the following additional findings is most likely in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The alveolar-arterial (A-a) gradient compares the oxygenation status of alveoli and arterial blood. The cause of a decreased A-a gradient is unknown. While the A-a gradient is normal in patients with hypoventilation and low levels of inspired oxygen, it becomes elevated when V/Q mismatch, shunting, and/or limited diffusion occur. The features of SLE seen here indicate that this patient is at increased risk for interstitial lung disease, which manifests with an increased A-a gradient.

B) INCORRECT:

Patients with clinical features that suggest SLE, as is the case here, are at risk of developing pulmonary hypertension. Pulmonary hypertension and an increase in right ventricular afterload cause right-sided filling pressures to increase. Therefore, an increase rather than decrease in right atrial pressure is likely to occur.

C) INCORRECT:

Airway resistance is typically increased in obstructive lung disease. However, interstitial lung disease manifests with a restrictive pattern of lung involvement. Therefore, airway resistance would be normal rather than increased.

D) CORRECT:

Interstitial lung disease results in collagen deposition in the walls of alveoli and obliteration of blood vessels, which interferes with the ability of the alveoli to exchange gases with pulmonary capillaries. This group of disorders decreases the diffusion capacity of the lung for carbon monoxide (DLCO) and increases the A-a gradient.

E) INCORRECT:

Lung diseases such as emphysema are associated with increased lung compliance. The features of SLE seen here, however, suggest that this patient likely has restrictive lung disease. Restrictive lung diseases impair the ability of the lungs to expand, causing decreased rather than increased lung compliance.
questions.hint: In a middle-aged woman with a history of recurrent miscarriages, the features of anemia, oral ulcerations, joint pain, and annular (discoid) lesions in areas exposed to the sun raise suspicion for systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), a connective tissue disorder. SLE is known to cause interstitial lung disease, which manifests with a dry cough, dyspnea, and fine basal inspiratory crackles.

questions.text: A 63-year-old woman comes to the physician because of worsening shortness of breath, cough, and a 4-kg (8.8-lb) weight loss over the last year. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 35 years. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 92/min, respirations are 20/min, blood pressure is 124/78 mm Hg, and pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 93%. Physical examination shows decreased breath sounds. A flow-volume loop obtained via pulmonary function testing is shown. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's respiratory symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This flow-volume loop showing a concave upward expiratory limb in a patient with progressive respiratory symptoms, weight loss, and a history of smoking is indicative of emphysema secondary to chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. In emphysema, alveolar collapse due to loss of lung parenchyma leads to decreased flow rates during the latter part of expiration, creating the scooped-out appearance of the expiratory limb. In addition, the loop shifts to the left, because the residual volume is abnormally high due to air trapping and hyperinflation. Further causes of an obstructive pattern on a flow-volume loop include asthma, bronchiolitis, and bronchiectasis.

B) INCORRECT:

Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) is a potential cause of restrictive lung disease. This patient's smoking history puts her at risk for IPF, which commonly manifests with progressive dyspnea and cough. However, as in any restrictive lung disease, the flow-volume loop would show a substantially decreased total lung capacity due to the lung parenchyma's inability to fully expand (i.e., decreased compliance). The peak flow is decreased in IPF, but not as low as would be expected given the decreased lung volume. This is because expiratory flows are increased by the enhanced elastic recoil of fibrosed lung parenchyma.
Image Description:

Total lung capacity (∼ 3.25 L) and peak expiratory and inspiratory flows are substantially decreased because of the lung's decreased compliance. Note that due to the enhanced elastic recoil of fibrosed lung parenchyma, expiratory flow is not decreased as greatly as lung volume.

C) INCORRECT:

Endotracheal neoplasms (e.g., squamous cell carcinoma) can cause fixed upper airway obstruction. This patient's smoking history puts her at risk of endotracheal neoplasms, which commonly manifest with shortness of breath, cough, and weight loss. However, a fixed upper airway obstruction would cause flow limitation throughout respiration, showing flattening of both the inspiratory and expiratory limb on a flow-volume loop.
Image Description:

Expiratory and inspiratory flows are flattened and reduced as they are impeded by the fixed obstruction.

D) INCORRECT:

Neuromuscular weakness of the respiratory muscles can lead to shortness of breath, hypoxia, and (often ineffective) cough, all of which this patient has. Moreover, difficulty swallowing due to concomitant bulbar dysfunction may result in weight loss. Possible etiologies include amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, myasthenia gravis, and Guillain-Barré syndrome, for which there are no signs in this patient. Moreover, unlike the flow-volume loop in this patient, respiratory muscle weakness would show a restrictive pattern on spirometry with a nearly normal shaped flow-volume loop but with increased residual volume, decreased peak flow rates, and decreased total lung capacity.
Image Description:

Weakness of the respiratory muscles results in reduced expiratory and inspiratory flows, reduced total lung capacity (∼ 5.5 L), and an increased residual volume (∼ 2 L).

E) INCORRECT:

Asthma is an obstructive lung disease, and, thus, consistent with this patient's low-volume loop showing a concave upward expiratory limb. Moreover, chronic cough, dyspnea, hypoxia and decreased breath sounds on auscultation are common features of chronic asthma. However, although new-onset asthma in late adulthood is possible, this patient's long-standing history of smoking, recent weight loss, and the absence of a history of atopy or allergic disease make a different diagnosis more likely.
Image Description:

Expiratory flow is impaired by narrowed airways. Therefore, the peak expiratory flow rate is lower than normal with a slightly concave (scooped) curve toward the residual volume. The residual volume is abnormally high (∼ 2 L), as the narrowed airways have prevented a full expiration.

F) INCORRECT:

The most common causes of unilateral mainstem obstruction are foreign body aspiration, which can easily be ruled out here, and tumors. Indeed, progressive cough, dyspnea, and weight loss in a patient with a smoking history should raise suspicion for respiratory malignancy. Moreover, unilateral mainstem obstruction would also show increased residual volume on flow-volume loop due to the impaired expiration of the air in the obstructed airway. However, in contrast to the flow-volume loop in this patient, the shape of the inspiratory and expiratory limb would typically be normal with a decreased vital capacity. During forceful expiration, the flow would quickly reach a peak flow below normal and then decline nearly linearly to the residual volume.
Image Description:

The shape of the loop is normal, but peak expiratory and inspiratory flow rates are reduced as air can enter only the nonobstructed portion of lung. The residual volume is greater than normal ( ∼ 3 L), because air in the obstructed airway cannot be fully exhaled.
questions.hint: Chest x-ray of this patient would likely show pulmonary hyperinflation, diaphragmatic flattening, and hyperlucency.

questions.text:
The response options for the next 2 items are the same. Select one answer for each item in the set.
For each patient with a cough, select the most likely diagnosis.
A 66-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-month history of episodic cough. She reports that the cough is nonproductive and worse when she lies down. She has smoked half a pack of cigarettes daily for 25 years. She has hypertension and coronary artery disease. Current medications include losartan, aspirin, and pravastatin. Her temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 84/min, respirations are 21/min, and blood pressure is 144/85 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 94%. Pulmonary examination shows mild bibasilar crackles. Cardiac examination shows an S3 gallop. Spirometry shows an FEV1:FVC ratio of 88% and an FEV1 of 90%. The diffusion capacity of the lung (DLCO) is decreased.
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patients with emphysema can present with dry cough and decreased DLCO (due to alveolar destruction) on spirometry and cigarette smoking is a risk factor for emphysema. However, chest auscultation would disclose decreased breath sounds and/or wheezes (due to small airway collapse) rather than bibasilar crackles. Furthermore, spirometry would show decreased FEV1 and a decreased FEV1:FVC, indicating an obstructive lung disease.

B) INCORRECT:

Upper airway cough syndrome (UACS) can manifest with a dry cough. However, patients with UACS would also display symptoms of rhinitis (e.g., sneezing, rhinorrhea), frequent throat clearing, and/or hoarseness. Furthermore, UACS does not affect the lower airway and therefore does not explain the crackles or spirometric findings in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Gastrointestinal reflux disease (GERD) can manifest as a dry chronic cough with nocturnal exacerbation (due to the recumbent position during sleep) as a result of laryngeal irritation or aspiration of gastric contents into the lower airways. However, patients with GERD also present with a history of retrosternal burning pain, dysphagia, and regurgitation, which this patient does not have. Furthermore, GERD does not explain the bibasilar crackles, spirometric findings, and the S3 gallop in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Infectious pneumonia can manifest with a cough, crackles, spirometric findings of restrictive lung disease (e.g., normal FEV1, normal FEV1:FVC), and decreased DLCO. However, the protracted onset of the patient's current symptoms and lack of any signs of infection (e.g., fever) makes an infectious etiology highly unlikely. Furthermore, the crackles would be localized to the area(s) of pulmonary consolidation, and bibasilar crackles and an S3 gallop would not be expected.

E) INCORRECT:

Hypersensitivity pneumonitis can manifest with a chronic dry cough, bibasilar crackles, spirometric findings of restrictive lung disease (e.g., normal FEV1, normal FEV1:FVC), and decreased DLCO. However, this patient does not have a history of exposure to the antigens that trigger hypersensitivity pneumonitis (e.g., hay, mold, bird excreta). In addition, the presence of an S3 gallop and other cardiovascular risk factors in this patient makes a different diagnosis more likely.

F) INCORRECT:

Bronchial asthma can manifest with dry cough in patients with risk factors such as aspirin use and cigarette smoking. However, physical examination would show diffuse wheezes rather than bibasilar crackles. In addition, spirometric findings of obstructive lung disease (e.g., decreased FEV1, decreased FEV1:FVC) and normal or increased DLCO would be expected. This patient's S3 gallop and other cardiovascular risk factors suggest another diagnosis.

G) INCORRECT:

ACE inhibitors, which are used to treat hypertension, can also cause a dry cough (due to decreased bradykinin breakdown). However, this patient's hypertension is being treated with losartan, an angiotensin receptor blocker, which is not typically associated with a cough. Moreover, a bradykinin-induced cough would not be associated with crackles, orthopnea, or a restrictive lung disease pattern on spirometry.

H) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary fibrosis can manifest with a dry cough, bibasilar crackles, decreased DLCO, and spirometric findings of restrictive lung disease (e.g., normal FEV1, normal FEV1:FVC). Also, cigarette smoking is a significant risk factor for pulmonary fibrosis. However, the presence of an S3 gallop and other cardiovascular risk factors (e.g., coronary artery disease, hypertension) in this patient makes a different diagnosis more likely.

I) INCORRECT:

Lung cancer is an important differential diagnosis in this patient presenting with dry cough, particularly considering her history of smoking, which is a significant risk factor for developing lung cancer. However, bibasilar crackles and an S3 gallop would not be expected with lung cancer.

J) CORRECT:

Dry cough that is worse when lying down, fine inspiratory crackles at the lung bases, and an S3 gallop on auscultation in a patient with multiple risk factors (e.g., hypertension, smoking, coronary artery disease) suggest congestive heart failure. The spirometric findings of restrictive lung disease (e.g., normal FEV1, normal FEV1:FVC) and decreased DLCOare due to cardiogenic pulmonary edema, which prevents full lung expansion and good gas exchange at the alveoli. Pulmonary edema usually indicates severe or decompensated heart failure, which will require aggressive diuresis (e.g., furosemide) to reduce volume overload.

K) INCORRECT:

Chronic bronchitis can manifest with cough and crackles and cigarette smoking is a risk factor for this condition. However, the cough would be productive, and must be present for at least three months per year for two consecutive years before chronic bronchitis can be diagnosed. In addition, patients with chronic bronchitis would have spirometric findings of obstructive lung disease (e.g., decreased FEV1, decreased FEV1:FVC) and normal DLCO.

L) INCORRECT:

Bronchiectasis would manifest with a chronic cough and crackles. However, in patients with bronchiectasis, the cough would be productive and the crackles would manifest diffusely rather than at the lung bases. In addition, spirometric findings of obstructive lung disease (e.g., decreased FEV1, decreased FEV1:FVC) and normal DLCO would be expected.
questions.hint: This patient's cough is most likely to improve after administration of furosemide.

questions.text:
For each patient with a cough, select the most likely diagnosis.
A 68-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of episodic cough. He reports that the cough is nonproductive and worse at night and when he walks to buy groceries. He has not had chest pain, hemoptysis, palpitations, or heartburn. He smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years but quit 8 years ago when his granddaughter was born. He has hypertension and osteoarthritis of the right hip. Current medications include hydrochlorothiazide and celecoxib. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 71/min, respirations are 19/min, and blood pressure is 139/85 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 97%. Pulmonary examination shows diffuse end-expiratory wheezing. Cardiac examination shows no murmurs, rubs, or gallops. Spirometry shows an FEV1:FVC ratio of 60% and an FEV1 of 65%. The diffusion capacity of the lung (DLCO) is normal.
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Emphysema can cause a chronic dry cough, end-expiratory wheezing (due to small airway collapse), and spirometric findings of obstructive lung disease (e.g., ↓ FEV1, ↓ FEV1:FVC ratio) and a history of smoking is a significant risk factor for emphysema. However, emphysema results in a decreased DLCO whereas this patient's DLCO is normal. Furthermore, the onset of cough 8 years after complete smoking cessation makes a different diagnosis more likely.

B) INCORRECT:

Upper airway cough syndrome (UACS) can manifest with a chronic dry cough. However, UACS is associated with symptoms of rhinitis (e.g., sneezing, rhinorrhea), frequent throat clearing, and/or hoarseness, which are not seen here. In addition, UACS does not affect the lower airway and, therefore, does not explain the wheezing or spirometric findings in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Gastrointestinal reflux disease (GERD) can manifest as a dry chronic cough with nocturnal exacerbation (due to the recumbent position during sleep) as a result of laryngeal irritation or aspiration of gastric contents into the lower airways. However, patients with GERD typically present with a history of heartburn, which is not seen here. Furthermore, GERD does not explain the wheezing or spirometric findings in this patient, and it is not exacerbated by exercise (i.e., walking to buy groceries).

D) INCORRECT:

Infectious pneumonia can manifest with a cough. However, the protracted onset of this patient's current symptoms with no signs of infection (e.g., fever) makes an infectious etiology highly unlikely. Furthermore, chest auscultation in patients with infectious pneumonia typically reveals coarse inspiratory crackles rather than wheezes, and spirometric findings of restrictive lung disease (normal or increased FEV1:FVC ratio) and decreased DLCO are expected, not the decreased FEV1:FVC ratio and normal DLCO seen here.

E) INCORRECT:

Hypersensitivity pneumonitis can manifest with a dry chronic cough. However, chest auscultation in patients with hypersensitivity pneumonitis typically reveals fine inspiratory crackles rather than wheezes. In addition, spirometric findings of restrictive lung disease (normal or increased FEV1:FVC ratio) and decreased DLCO are expected, not the decreased FEV1:FVC ratio and normal DLCO seen here. Furthermore, this patient does not have a history of exposure to the antigens that trigger hypersensitivity pneumonitis (e.g., hay, mold, bird excreta).

F) CORRECT:

Bronchial asthma, which is characterized by airway hyperresponsiveness and bronchial obstruction, can manifest at any age. In young patients, asthma is typically caused by a type I hypersensitivity to an allergen. In older patients, nonallergic pathologies (e.g., irritant inhalation, exertion, stress, medications, GERD) can also cause bronchial asthma. Clinical features of bronchial asthma include a chronic dry cough with nocturnal and exercise-induced exacerbation and diffuse end-expiratory wheezing. Spirometry shows features of obstructive lung disease, such as decreased FEV1 and decreased FEV1:FVC ratio. The airway obstruction in bronchial asthma characteristically worsens following a methacholine challenge test and improves following the inhalation of a bronchodilator (e.g., albuterol). Since alveolar gas exchange is not impaired in bronchial asthma, the DLCO is usually normal or can be slightly increased as a result of hyperinflation without alveolar destruction.

G) INCORRECT:

Aspirin and other COX-1 inhibiting NSAIDs can cause a pseudoallergic reaction known as aspirin-exacerbated respiratory disease (AERD), which can manifest with a chronic, dry cough and wheezing. However, additional clinical features, such as recurrent rhinosinusitis and nasal polyps, are expected. In addition, this patient is currently on celecoxib, a selective COX-2 inhibitor, which is usually tolerated in patients with AERD. Similarly, ACE inhibitors can result in a dry cough and wheezing, but this patient's hypertension is being treated with hydrochlorothiazide, which does not cause pulmonary side effects.

H) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary fibrosis can manifest with a dry cough and a past history of smoking is a significant risk factor for pulmonary fibrosis. However, chest auscultation in patients with pulmonary fibrosis typically reveals fine bibasilar inspiratory crackles rather than diffuse wheezes. In addition, spirometric findings of restrictive lung disease (normal or increased FEV1:FVC ratio) and decreased DLCO are expected in patients with pulmonary fibrosis, not the decreased FEV1:FVC ratio and normal DLCO seen here.

I) INCORRECT:

Lung cancer can manifest with a cough and, in advanced stages, wheezing due to bronchial obstruction by the tumor. In addition, a history of smoking is a significant risk factor for lung cancer. However, the wheezes are typically localized to the site of bronchial obstruction, unlike the diffuse wheezes seen here, and other features of malignancy, such as weight loss, are expected.

J) INCORRECT:

Congestive heart failure (CHF) can manifest with a chronic cough and, occasionally, wheezing (i.e., cardiac asthma) with spirometric findings of obstructive lung disease (e.g., ↓ FEV1, ↓ FEV1:FVC ratio). These findings, however, typically occur when patients with CHF develop acute decompensation. In CHF without acute decompensation, spirometry usually shows findings of restrictive lung disease (normal or increased FEV1:FVC ratio). In addition, patients with CHF typically have decreased rather than normal DLCO (due to pulmonary edema) as well as other clinical features, such as peripheral edema, jugular venous distention, and fine, inspiratory crackles.

K) INCORRECT:

Chronic bronchitis manifests with cough, wheezing, spirometric findings of obstructive lung disease (e.g., ↓ FEV1, ↓ FEV1:FVC ratio), and normal DLCO. However, the cough in chronic bronchitis is productive, unlike the nonproductive cough seen here, and the cough must have been present for at least 3 months per year in 2 consecutive years before chronic bronchitis can be diagnosed. In addition, chronic bronchitis is typically associated with active cigarette smoking whereas this patient quit smoking 8 years ago.

L) INCORRECT:

Bronchiectasis manifests with a chronic cough, spirometric findings of obstructive lung disease (e.g., ↓ FEV1, ↓ FEV1:FVC ratio), normal DLCO, and, occasionally, wheezing, all of which are consistent with this patient's presentation. However, in patients with bronchiectasis, the cough is typically productive, and chest auscultation would also reveal coarse crackles, which are not seen here.
questions.hint: This patient's FEV1:FVC ratio will most likely return to the normal range shortly after the administration of albuterol.

questions.text:
A 6-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her parents because of a 2-month history of intermittent wheezing and nonproductive cough. Her symptoms worsened after she and her family moved to the countryside 1 month ago. The child has a history of atopic dermatitis. Her temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 95/min, respirations are 29/min, and blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg. Bilateral scattered wheezes are heard on auscultation of the chest. Pulmonary function testing is most likely to show which of the following sets of findings?



FEV1

FVC
DLCO

Total lung capacity



A
Decreased
normal
decreased
increased


B
Decreased
decreased
normal
decreased


C
Decreased
decreased
decreased
decreased


D
Normal
normal
decreased
normal


E
Decreased
normal
increased
increased
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This set of findings is compatible with emphysema, a form of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). Emphysema decreases the surface area available for gaseous exchange, resulting in decreased DLCO. COPD can also manifest with wheezing, an obstructive pattern on pulmonary function tests including decreased FEV1, and, in the case of air trapping, increased total lung capacity with normal or decreased FVC. Although early-onset emphysema can occur in patients with certain rare hereditary disorders (e.g., alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency), this young girl most likely has bronchial asthma rather than COPD.

B) INCORRECT:

This set of findings is compatible with restrictive lung disease (RLD) due to extrapulmonary causes (e.g., obesity, neuromuscular disease, thoracic deformities). FEV1, FVC, and total lung capacity (TLC) are decreased but DLCO is typically normal, as the intrinsic quality of the lung is not affected. In RLD due to extrapulmonary causes, the FEV1:FVC ratio is typically normal because FVC and FEV1 decrease in equal proportion.

C) INCORRECT:

This set of findings is compatible with restrictive lung disease (RLD) caused by intrinsic lung impairment (e.g., interstitial lung disease, pneumonia, pulmonary edema). All lung volumes and capacities, including FEV1, FVC, and total lung capacity, are decreased as a result of the lungs' impaired ability to expand (decreased compliance). In RLD caused by intrinsic lung impairment, the FEV1:FVC ratio is normal or increased because the decrease in FVC is more substantial than the decrease in FEV1. Additionally, DLCO is decreased because the surface area for gaseous exchange is diminished.

D) INCORRECT:

This set of findings is compatible with primary pulmonary vascular disease (e.g., pulmonary embolism, idiopathic pulmonary hypertension), severe anemia, and carboxyhemoglobinemia (e.g., in smokers, carbon monoxide poisoning). As these conditions do not cause a restrictive or obstructive pattern, lung volumes and capacities are not affected. These conditions instead decrease lung perfusion, resulting in decreased DLCO.

E) CORRECT:

This set of findings is consistent with BA. FEV1 decreases as a result of increased airway resistance (due to airway narrowing). Total lung capacity (TLC) and FVC can be normal but in the case of severe BA, air trapping occurs, resulting in increased residual volume and increased TLC; FVC might also decrease if air trapping is severe. In BA, the diffusion capacity of the lung for carbon monoxide (DLCO) is normal or increased. The increase in DLCO is thought to be due to a combination of increased pulmonary capillary bed recruitment and increases in alveolar pressure and/or surface area (as a result of air trapping and hyperinflation). In BA and other obstructive lung diseases (e.g., chronic obstructive pulmonary disease), the FEV1:FVC ratio is typically decreased because the decrease in FEV1 is more substantial than the decrease in FVC.

Pulmonary function tests (PFTs), such as spirometry and single-breath diffusion capacity (DLCO measurement), can be performed in children who are able to understand and follow instructions for breathing maneuvers (typically children older than 5 years of age). Spirometry is used to determine the severity of BA and to guide therapy.
questions.hint: In a patient with a history of atopy, wheezing and nonproductive cough that worsened after probable exposure to allergens (the family moved to the countryside) are suggestive of bronchial asthma (BA).

questions.text:
A 20-year-old competitive runner reports that she is having difficulty breathing when she runs a mile-long event for her college track team. During the race, she has more trouble moving air with inspiration than with expiration. Premedicating with albuterol 10 minutes before running provides little relief.
Her physical examination is normal, and her inhaler technique is observed to be excellent.
A chest radiograph is normal. On postexercise spirometry testing, all of her expiratory values are over 100% of predicted. The shape of the expiratory limb of the flow-volume loop is normal; however, the inspiratory loop is flat, and her inspiratory flow rates are decreased.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Adenoid hyperplasia can cause inspiratory symptoms but would not cause extrathoracic airflow obstruction on spirometry.

B) CORRECT:

This case demonstrates many classic features of vocal-cord dysfunction — the problem is occurring in a highly competitive female athlete, the patient has more difficulty with inspiration than with expiration, and premedication with albuterol is not effective. When the patient is symptomatic, the inspiratory limb of the flow-volume loop is flat, signifying extrathoracic airflow obstruction; in contrast, when the patient is asymptomatic, spirometry would appear normal. The gold standard for diagnosing vocal-cord dysfunction is laryngoscopy, which demonstrates paradoxical vocal-cord motion during spontaneous or induced symptoms; the vocal cords adduct anteriorly either during inspiration or throughout the respiratory cycle, leaving an open posterior glottic chink.

Key learning point: The diagnosis that should be considered for a patient with exertional dyspnea whose postexercise spirometry results show an abnormal inspiratory limb of the flow-volume loop is vocal-cord dysfunction. Treatment involves relaxation exercises for the upper airway.

C) INCORRECT:

Tracheomalacia can alter the appearance of the flow-volume loop, but the expiratory (not inspiratory) limb would be flattened, reflecting the intrathoracic etiology of obstruction.

D) INCORRECT:

Gastroesophageal reflux disease has been associated with cough, laryngitis, and asthma, but it would not manifest with dyspnea and inspiratory abnormalities.

E) INCORRECT:

Exercise-induced bronchospasm can usually be prevented by premedicating with albuterol. Spirometry would look normal if the patient was currently asymptomatic, or it would demonstrate expiratory coving (or concavity) with a reduced FEV1 /FVC ratio.

questions.text: A previously healthy 60-year-old man presents with progressively worsening shortness of breath for the past 2 months. He does not experience shortness of breath at rest. He also occasionally has a dry cough. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 40 years. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 94/min, respirations are 21/min, and blood pressure is 136/88 mm Hg. Lung auscultation reveals a prolonged expiratory phase and end-expiratory wheezing. Spirometry shows an FEV1:FVC ratio of 62% after bronchodilator inhalation, an FEV1 of 60% of predicted, and a total lung capacity of 125% of predicted. The diffusion capacity of the lung (DLCO) is decreased. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Interstitial lung disease (ILD) results in progressively worsening shortness of breath, a dry cough, decreased FEV1, and decreased DLCO. Smoking is also a risk factor for ILD and weight loss can occasionally occur. However, ILD results in restrictive lung disease; the TLC would therefore be decreased, and FEV1/FVC would be normal or increased. Moreover, patients with ILD typically have bibasilar inspiratory crackles on auscultation rather than end-expiratory wheezing.

B) INCORRECT:

Subacute hypersensitivity pneumonitis can result in dyspnea that worsens over the course of 2 months, a dry cough, weight loss, decreased FEV1, and decreased DLCO. However, subacute hypersensitivity pneumonitis typically results in restrictive (or mixed restrictive/obstructive) lung disease; total lung capacity would therefore be reduced. Moreover, patients with hypersensitivity pneumonitis typically have bibasilar inspiratory crackles on auscultation rather than wheezing and a history of occupational exposure to an allergen (e.g., animal proteins, mold).

C) CORRECT:

Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) manifests with progressively worsening dyspnea, end-expiratory wheezing, a prolonged expiratory phase, and spirometry findings of a decreased FEV1/FVC ratio, a decreased FEV1, and increased TLC (due to increased lung compliance). Smoking is responsible for over 90% of cases of COPD. Emphysema-predominant COPD can manifest with cachexia (due to increased work of breathing) and an occasional dry cough. Decreased DLCO levels indicate a decreased surface area for air exchange from the destruction of the alveoli present in emphysema.

The patient has an FEV1 between 50 and 80% of the predicted value, which means he has moderate COPD (GOLD class 2) and should therefore be treated with inhaled long-acting beta-2 agonists such as salmeterol or formoterol. Patients with COPD should receive the pneumococcal vaccine every 5–6 years and the influenza vaccine annually, and should also be counseled on smoking cessation.

Key learning point: Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease is characterized by progressive dyspnea, obstructive spirometry (decreased FEV1/FVC), increased total lung capacity, decreased DLCO, and is most commonly caused by long-term smoking.

D) INCORRECT:

Bronchiectasis can result in progressively worsening dyspnea, cough, wheezing, weight loss, and features of obstructive lung disease (e.g., ↓ FEV1:FVC ratio). However, patients with bronchiectasis would have a productive cough with thick, foul-smelling sputum (due to anaerobic infection) and coarse inspiratory crackles on auscultation.

E) INCORRECT:

Bronchial asthma would result in breathlessness, cough, wheezing, decreased FEV1, and decreased FEV1/FVC. The TLC may also be increased in some patients. However, bronchial asthma is typically characterized by acute exacerbations, in contrast to this patient's 2 months of progressive dyspnea. Moreover, weight loss would not be expected, and DLCO would be normal or mildly increased.
questions.hint: This patient has decreased FEV1 (< 80% of predicted value), decreased FEV1:FVC (< 70%), and increased total lung capacity (TLC) (> 120% of predicted). A chest x-ray of patients with this diagnosis often shows hyperlucency of the lung fields and bilateral diaphragmatic flattening.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man comes to the office because of a 10-month history of progressive shortness of breath and a cough productive of a small amount of white phlegm. Bilateral end-expiratory wheezing is heard on auscultation of the chest. Pulmonary function tests show total lung capacity that is 108% of predicted, an FEV1 that is 56% of predicted, and an FEV1:FVC ratio of 62%. Which of the following interventions is most likely to slow the decline in FEV1 in individuals with this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

COPD is a preventable lung disease characterized by airway obstruction due to inflammation of the small airways and is primarily caused by long-term smoking. Smoking cessation is the single most important measure to slow the decline in lung function at all stages of COPD. It has been shown that the earlier the cessation is achieved, the greater the benefit for lung function. Other measures that improve lung function of COPD patients include treatment with inhaled corticosteroids and bronchodilators.

B) INCORRECT:

Physiotherapy with breathing exercises as part of pulmonary rehabilitation is a supportive measure in the treatment of COPD patients. It has been shown to improve symptoms, exercise capacity, and quality of life. However, there is an intervention with a greater impact on the rate of decline in FEV1..

C) INCORRECT:

Salmeterol is a long-acting beta agonist used as combination or monotherapy in patients with COPD. This drug has been shown to significantly decrease exacerbation rates and improve lung function. However, there is an intervention with a greater impact on the rate of decline in FEV1..

D) INCORRECT:

Fluticasone is an inhaled corticosteroid used in combination with a long-acting bronchodilator in patients with severe COPD. Even though this combination therapy has been shown to improve lung function and exacerbations rates, fluticasone monotherapy seems to have little impact on the rate of decline in FEV1..

E) INCORRECT:

Intravenous alpha-1 antitrypsin (AAT) replacement therapy is used in patients with COPD due to severe AAT deficiency, a genetic disorder presenting with liver disease as well as early-onset panacinar emphysema. However, severe AAT deficiency is rare and would usually manifest earlier in life with hepatic involvement (e.g., hepatitis, cirrhosis, hepatocellular carcinoma).
questions.hint: This patient's history of dyspnea and productive cough combined with a decreased FEV1, decreased FEV1:FVC ratio, and increased total lung capacity make chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) the most likely diagnosis.

questions.text:
A 68-year-old man presents with progressive shortness of breath for eight months. He denies a history of smoking or environmental exposures. Physical examination reveals fine bibasilar crackles and digital clubbing. He reports scant sputum and no improvement with bronchodilators (see report).
Pulmonary function testing: Reduced total lung capacity with a normal FEV1/FVC ratio
Which of the following diagnoses is most likely?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Asthma typically presents with episodic dyspnea, wheezing, and reversibility with bronchodilators. Pulmonary function tests show an obstructive pattern with a reduced FEV1/FVC ratio that improves post-bronchodilator. The patient's persistent symptoms, lack of bronchodilator response, and restrictive pattern on testing, along with crackles and clubbing, are not characteristic of asthma.

B) INCORRECT:

Chronic bronchitis is associated with a productive cough and mucus hypersecretion, typically in smokers. It presents with an obstructive pattern on pulmonary function tests, characterized by a reduced FEV1/FVC ratio. The patient's scant sputum production, fine crackles, and restrictive pattern on pulmonary function testing are inconsistent with chronic bronchitis.

C) CORRECT:

Pulmonary fibrosis is an interstitial lung disease that manifests with fibrotic remodeling of the lung parenchyma, leading to decreased lung compliance. Reduced total lung capacity with a a preserved FEV1/FVC ratio on pulmonary function testing differentiates restrictive from obstructive lung disease. The clinical presentation of progressive dyspnea, bibasilar inspiratory crackles, and digital clubbing indicate interstitial lung disease. The lack of significant improvement with bronchodilators supports a diagnosis centered on parenchymal scarring rather than airway hyperreactivity.

Key learning point: A restrictive spirometry pattern is characterized by reduced lung volumes and is commonly seen in conditions like pulmonary fibrosis, whereas obstructive patterns are seen in diseases like asthma and bronchiectasis.
Image Description:

(1) The top graph is a normal flow-volume loop and a time-volume curve used to determine the FEV1.
(2) Obstructive lung diseases result in a concave flow-volume loop due to increased resistance. Absolute FEV1, as well as FEV1 relative to vital capacity (FEV1/FVC), is diminished.
(3) Restrictive lung diseases result in a narrowed flow-volume loop due to reduced vital capacity and compliance. Absolute FEV1 is diminished, but not in relation to vital capacity (FEV1/FVC).

D) INCORRECT:

Bronchiectasis is characterized by recurrent infections and copious purulent sputum production. It usually shows an obstructive or mixed pattern on pulmonary function tests. The patient's scant sputum, restrictive pattern on testing, and absence of recurrent infections make bronchiectasis unlikely.

questions.text:
A 29-year-old woman presents to the Outpatient Clinic with intermittent episodes of wheezing, chest tightness, and shortness of breath that typically occur at night. She has no significant smoking history. Physical examination is normal, and resting spirometry is unremarkable. She remains symptomatic, and her symptoms suggest possible mild asthma.
Which of the following is the most appropriate test to help confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Allergy skin testing identifies IgE-mediated hypersensitivity but does not assess airway hyperresponsiveness. It is useful for identifying allergen triggers in established asthma but does not confirm the diagnosis of asthma itself.

B) INCORRECT:
