High-resolution chest CT scans are used to identify structural lung diseases, not functional airway disorders like asthma. They do not assess airway hyperresponsiveness, which is crucial for diagnosing asthma in patients with normal spirometry and intermittent symptoms.

C) CORRECT:

The methacholine challenge test is used to confirm asthma in patients with normal spirometry but suspected airway hyperreactivity. Methacholine, a cholinergic agonist, induces bronchoconstriction in susceptible individuals, evidenced by a 20% reduction in forced expiratory volume in 1 second (FEV1). This test is highly sensitive for detecting bronchial hyperreactivity, which is a hallmark of asthma, especially when baseline pulmonary function tests are unremarkable.

Key learning point: In patients with symptoms suggestive of asthma but normal spirometry, a methacholine challenge test can be used to assess airway hyperresponsiveness and help confirm the diagnosis of asthma.

D) INCORRECT:

Chest radiography is not used to confirm asthma, as it does not assess airway hyperreactivity. It is more useful for excluding other conditions like pneumonia or interstitial lung disease. In mild asthma, chest radiographs are often normal and do not provide the necessary diagnostic information.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man comes to your clinic with a 2-month history of progressively worsening shortness of breath. He does not have shortness of breath at rest and occasionally has a dry cough. He has a 40-year history of smoking one pack of cigarettes daily. His temperature is 37.0°C, pulse is 94/min, respirations are 21/min, and blood pressure is 136/88 mm Hg. On lung auscultation, there is a prolonged expiratory phase and end-expiratory wheezing. Spirometry shows an FEV1:FVC ratio of 62% after bronchodilator inhalation, an FEV1 of 60% of predicted, and a total lung capacity of 125% of predicted. The diffusion capacity of the lung (DLCO) is decreased. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Interstitial lung disease (ILD) results in progressively worsening shortness of breath, a dry cough, decreased FEV1, and decreased DLCO. Smoking is also a risk factor for ILD and weight loss can occasionally occur. However, ILD results in restrictive lung disease; the TLC would therefore be decreased, and FEV1/FVC would be normal or increased. Moreover, patients with ILD typically have bibasilar inspiratory crackles on auscultation rather than end-expiratory wheezing.

B) INCORRECT:

Subacute hypersensitivity pneumonitis can result in dyspnea that worsens over the course of 2 months, a dry cough, weight loss, decreased FEV1, and decreased DLCO. However, subacute hypersensitivity pneumonitis typically results in restrictive (or mixed restrictive/obstructive) lung disease; total lung capacity would therefore be reduced. Moreover, patients with hypersensitivity pneumonitis typically have bibasilar inspiratory crackles on auscultation rather than wheezing and a history of occupational exposure to an allergen (e.g., animal proteins, mold).

C) INCORRECT:

Bronchiectasis can result in progressively worsening dyspnea, cough, wheezing, weight loss, and features of obstructive lung disease (e.g., ↓ FEV1:FVC ratio). However, patients with bronchiectasis would have a productive cough with thick, foul-smelling sputum (due to anaerobic infection) and coarse inspiratory crackles on auscultation.

D) INCORRECT:

Bronchial asthma would result in breathlessness, cough, wheezing, decreased FEV1, and decreased FEV1/FVC. The TLC may also be increased in some patients. However, bronchial asthma is typically characterized by acute exacerbations, in contrast to this patient's 2 months of progressive dyspnea. Moreover, weight loss would not be expected, and DLCO would be normal or mildly increased.

E) CORRECT:

Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) manifests with progressively worsening dyspnea, end-expiratory wheezing, a prolonged expiratory phase, and spirometry findings of a decreased FEV1/FVC ratio, a decreased FEV1, and increased TLC (due to increased lung compliance). Smoking is responsible for over 90% of cases of COPD. Emphysema-predominant COPD can manifest with cachexia (due to increased work of breathing) and an occasional dry cough. Decreased DLCO levels indicate a decreased surface area for air exchange from the destruction of the alveoli present in emphysema.

The patient has an FEV1 between 50 and 80% of the predicted value, which means he has moderate COPD (GOLD class 2) and should therefore be treated with inhaled long-acting beta-2 agonists such as salmeterol or formoterol. Patients with COPD should receive the pneumococcal vaccine every 5–6 years and the influenza vaccine annually, and should also be counseled on smoking cessation.

Key learning point: Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease is characterized by progressive dyspnea, obstructive spirometry (decreased FEV1/FVC), increased total lung capacity, decreased DLCO, and is strongly associated with a history of smoking.
questions.hint: This patient has decreased FEV1 (< 80% of predicted value), decreased FEV1:FVC (< 70%), and increased total lung capacity (TLC) (> 120% of predicted). A chest x-ray of patients with this diagnosis often shows hyperlucency of the lung fields and bilateral diaphragmatic flattening.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman with hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus comes to your clinic because of increasing shortness of breath and a dry cough over the past 6 months. She has a 40-year history of smoking one pack of cigarettes daily. On chest auscultation, there are scattered expiratory wheezes in both lung fields. Spirometry shows an FEV1:FVC ratio of 65% and an FEV1 of 70% of predicted. Her diffusing capacity for carbon monoxide (DLCO) is 42% of predicted. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary fibrosis can cause progressive dyspnea and a dry cough but chest auscultation would typically reveal basal fine inspiratory crackles and spirometry would show features of restrictive lung disease (normal or increased FEV1:FVC ratio).

B) CORRECT:

This patient's clinical features (progressive dyspnea, dry cough, wheezes) and features of obstructive lung disease on spirometry are suggestive of emphysema, which is a clinical phenotype of COPD caused by the destruction of alveolar walls. Decreased DLCO, as seen in this patient, is a typical finding of emphysema that reflects the reduction of gas exchange due to a loss of diffusion area. The most common cause of emphysema is chronic smoking, which induces oxidative damage, inflammation, and activation of neutrophil and macrophage elastases. A less common cause is alpha-1-antitrypsin deficiency, which should be suspected in the case of early-onset emphysema or emphysema among non-smokers.

Key learning point: Emphysema is characterized by obstructive lung disease with decreased DLCO due to alveolar wall destruction and loss of gas exchange surface area.

C) INCORRECT:

Bronchiectasis can cause dyspnea, cough, wheezes, and features of obstructive lung disease on spirometry. However, patients with bronchiectasis would have a cough productive of purulent, foul-smelling sputum, and coarse expiratory and inspiratory crackles would be present in most patients. Moreover, DLCO is typically unaffected in individuals with bronchiectasis.

D) INCORRECT:

Bronchial asthma can cause dyspnea, a dry cough, wheeze, and features of obstructive lung disease on spirometry. However, DLCO in patients with bronchial asthma is usually normal or increased (due to increased perfusion in the lung apices) unlike in this patient with decreased DLCO. Moreover, the symptoms of asthma typically manifest as acute exacerbations unlike the progressive worsening of symptoms over 6 months here.

E) INCORRECT:

Smoking is a risk factor for developing chronic bronchitis, which is one of the clinical phenotypes of COPD. Chronic bronchitis can cause dyspnea, cough, wheezes, and features of obstructive lung disease on spirometry. However, chronic bronchitis can only be diagnosed if the patient has a productive cough on most days of 3 consecutive months in a year and this pattern of respiratory symptoms has been present for at least 2 consecutive years. Moreover, DLCO is usually not impaired by chronic bronchitis because there are no structural changes in alveoli that impair the diffusing capacity.
questions.hint: An FEV1:FVC ratio of < 70% and a reduced FEV1  < 80% on spirometry indicate an obstructive lung pathology.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man comes to your clinic with a 10-month history of progressive shortness of breath and a cough productive of a small amount of white phlegm. On auscultation of the chest, you hear bilateral end-expiratory wheezing. Pulmonary function tests show a total lung capacity that is 108% of predicted, an FEV1 that is 56% of predicted, and an FEV1:FVC ratio of 62%. Which one of the following interventions is most likely to slow the decline in FEV1 in individuals with this condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Fluticasone is an inhaled corticosteroid used in combination with a long-acting bronchodilator in patients with severe COPD. Even though this combination therapy has been shown to improve lung function and exacerbations rates, fluticasone monotherapy seems to have little impact on the rate of decline in FEV1..

B) INCORRECT:

Intravenous alpha-1 antitrypsin (AAT) replacement therapy is used in patients with COPD due to severe AAT deficiency, a genetic disorder presenting with liver disease as well as early-onset panacinar emphysema. However, severe AAT deficiency is rare and would usually manifest earlier in life with hepatic involvement (e.g., hepatitis, cirrhosis, hepatocellular carcinoma).

C) INCORRECT:

Salmeterol is a long-acting beta agonist used as combination or monotherapy in patients with COPD. This drug has been shown to significantly decrease exacerbation rates and improve lung function. However, there is an intervention with a greater impact on the rate of decline in FEV1..

D) INCORRECT:

Physiotherapy with breathing exercises as part of pulmonary rehabilitation is a supportive measure in the treatment of COPD patients. It has been shown to improve symptoms, exercise capacity, and quality of life. However, there is an intervention with a greater impact on the rate of decline in FEV1..

E) CORRECT:

COPD is a preventable lung disease characterized by airway obstruction due to inflammation of the small airways and is primarily caused by long-term smoking. Smoking cessation is the single most important measure to slow the decline in lung function at all stages of COPD. It has been shown that the earlier the cessation is achieved, the greater the benefit for lung function. Other measures that improve lung function of COPD patients include treatment with inhaled corticosteroids and bronchodilators.

Key learning point: Smoking cessation is the most effective intervention to slow the decline in lung function in patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease.
questions.hint: This patient's history of dyspnea and productive cough combined with a decreased FEV1, decreased FEV1:FVC ratio, and increased total lung capacity make chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) the most likely diagnosis.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presents to the ED with worsening dyspnea over 3 days. She has a history of asthma and shows prior spirometry results from 6 months ago: FEV₁ 2.1 L, FVC 3.8 L, PEF 320 L/min. Current peak flow measurement is 128 L/min. Age/height/sex predicted values are FEV₁ 2.4 L, FVC 3.9 L, PEF 350 L/min. She speaks in short phrases and uses accessory muscles. Which diagnostic test should be performed next?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

CBC is not the priority diagnostic test in severe asthma exacerbation. While a CBC may show mild leukocytosis (which is common in asthma exacerbations due to stress and inflammation), it is only indicated if concomitant bacterial pneumonia is suspected.

B) CORRECT:

Correct – of 128 L/min represents 40% of her personal best (320 L/min), indicating severe asthma exacerbation. Arterial blood gas analysis is indicated when PEF is ≤50% of predicted average value or personal best to assess for hypercapnia and respiratory acidosis. Personal best values are preferred over predicted values for severity assessment.

C) INCORRECT:

Chest radiographs are not routinely recommended in asthma exacerbations. They are indicated when there is suspected comorbidity such as pneumonia or pneumothorax, or when evaluating differential diagnoses. This patient's presentation is consistent with asthma exacerbation without concerning features suggesting complications.

D) INCORRECT:

Electrocardiogram should be considered in patients over 50 years with cardiovascular comorbidities or COPD-asthma overlap. However, this patient presents with typical asthma exacerbation symptoms and another diagnostic test takes priority for immediate severity assessment and management decisions.

E) INCORRECT:

Venous blood gas analysis cannot adequately assess for hypercapnia, which is crucial in severe asthma exacerbations. Rising PaCO₂ levels indicate respiratory muscle fatigue and impending respiratory failure. Arterial sampling is necessary for accurate CO₂ measurement in this clinical context.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman with chronic lung disease presents with progressive dyspnea over the past month. Her pulmonary function tests (PFTs) from 6 months ago showed FEV1 1.8 L (65% predicted); forced vital capacity (FVC) 2.2 L (68% predicted); FEV1/FVC ratio 0.82; total lung capacity (TLC) 4.2 L (70% predicted); and residual volume 1.1 L (95% predicted). She now has worsening exercise tolerance and an oxygen saturation of 88% on room air. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary rehabilitation is beneficial for patients with chronic lung disease but is not the immediate priority for a patient with acute hypoxemia.

B) INCORRECT:

Systemic corticosteroids may be considered for certain restrictive lung diseases such as interstitial lung disease or inflammatory conditions, but they are not the immediate priority for a patient with acute hypoxemia.

C) INCORRECT:

Chest physiotherapy may help with secretion clearance in certain conditions but does not address the immediate problem of hypoxemia in this patient with restrictive lung disease.

D) INCORRECT:

Bronchodilators are primarily indicated for obstructive lung disease. This patient's PFTs are consistent with restrictive lung disease (normal FEV1/FVC ratio and decreased TLC).

E) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient has restrictive lung disease, based on a normal FEV1/FVC ratio (0.82) and decreased TLC (70% predicted), and presents with hypoxemia (oxygen saturation 88% on room air). Supplemental oxygen is the most appropriate immediate intervention to address hypoxemia and improve oxygen delivery to tissues.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman with asthma presents with acute dyspnea and wheezing. She reports poor adherence to her inhaled corticosteroid. Vital signs are stable except for tachypnea. Initial peak expiratory flow is 240 L/min (60% of personal best). After nebulized bronchodilators, her dyspnea and wheezing have resolved, and repeat peak expiratory flow is 320 L/min. What is the most appropriate disposition?

choices.text: Discharge home with oral prednisone and continue as-needed bronchodilator
Continue nebulized bronchodilators for one additional hour and repeat PEF before disposition
Obtain arterial blood gas to confirm complete resolution before discharge

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct – The patient’s PEF improved from 60% to 80% of personal best with complete symptom resolution and stable vital signs. A PEF ≥70% of personal best and sustained clinical improvement indicate mild or resolved exacerbation suitable for outpatient management with a short course of oral corticosteroids and continued inhaled bronchodilator therapy.

B) INCORRECT:

Hospital admission is indicated for patients with incomplete response (PEF <70% of personal best) or risk factors for severe exacerbation.

C) INCORRECT:

ICU transfer is reserved for life-threatening asthma (PEF <40%, hypercapnia, or altered mental status). This patient’s improvement excludes that severity.

D) INCORRECT:

Further bronchodilator therapy is unnecessary once symptoms have resolved and PEF exceeds 70% of personal best.

E) INCORRECT:

Arterial blood gas analysis is indicated only in severe or nonresponsive asthma (PEF <50% or hypoxia). This patient’s clinical recovery and normal oxygen saturation make ABG testing unnecessary.

questions.text: A 52-year-old teacher with a 20-pack-year smoking history presents with progressive dyspnea over 6 months. She reports episodic wheezing that worsens with respiratory infections. Initial spirometry shows FEV1 of 1.6 L (55% predicted) and FEV1/FVC ratio of 0.62. Post-bronchodilator spirometry shows FEV1 of 1.9 L (65% predicted) and FEV1/FVC ratio of 0.65. What is the next most appropriate step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The post-bronchodilator FEV₁ increased by 300 mL and 18.8%, meeting criteria for significant bronchodilator responsiveness. This degree of reversibility suggests an asthma component, making LABA monotherapy inappropriate and potentially dangerous in patients with underlying asthma.

B) CORRECT:

Correct – The 300 mL (18.8%) improvement in FEV₁ meets both criteria for positive bronchodilator responsiveness (≥200 mL and ≥12% increase). This significant reversibility in the setting of smoking history suggests asthma-COPD overlap, which requires ICS-containing therapy as first-line treatment rather than bronchodilator monotherapy.

C) INCORRECT:

LAMA monotherapy would be appropriate for pure COPD with minimal reversibility, but the significant bronchodilator response indicates another reversible component. Bronchodilator monotherapy alone is insufficient for this degree of reversibility.

D) INCORRECT:

While chest CT may eventually be indicated for further evaluation, the significant bronchodilator responsiveness requires immediate initiation of another more appropriate therapy. Delaying treatment could lead to continued symptoms and potential exacerbations.

E) INCORRECT:

Although smoking cessation is important for long-term management, this patient's significant bronchodilator responsiveness indicates active reversible airway disease requiring pharmacological intervention in addition to smoking cessation counseling.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman with a history of COPD and hypertension presents with worsening shortness of breath for 2 days. She notes dyspnea at rest and mild chest tightness. Vital signs are BP, 95/60 mm Hg; P, 108; R, 26; SpO₂, 89% on room air. On examination, she appears uncomfortable, leaning forward, with decreased breath sounds and diffuse wheeze. Which diagnostic approach is most appropriate in the emergency department?

choices.text: Chest x-ray and arterial blood gas analysis

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Spirometry requires patient cooperation and stable respiratory status. Performing it during acute respiratory distress risks deterioration and delays critical stabilization. Pulmonary function testing is reserved for stable, outpatient evaluation of obstructive disease.

B) CORRECT:

Correct – This patient presents with acute respiratory distress requiring immediate stabilization and diagnostic evaluation. These studies provide essential information for acute management without delaying treatment. Chest x-ray identifies complications such as pneumonia, pneumothorax, or pulmonary edema, while arterial blood gas analysis guides oxygenation and ventilation strategies. In unstable patients, rapid bedside diagnostics take priority over formal pulmonary function testing.

C) INCORRECT:

Although pulmonary embolism can cause dyspnea, CT imaging should not precede stabilization or basic evaluation in a patient with hypoxia and possible COPD exacerbation. Advanced imaging is appropriate only after the patient is hemodynamically and respiratorily stable.

D) INCORRECT:

Point-of-care ultrasound can assist in evaluating dyspnea but cannot confirm or exclude obstructive lung disease.

E) INCORRECT:

Cardiac evaluation is useful when heart failure is suspected, but the presentation here is primarily obstructive.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman with hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus comes to the physician because of increasing shortness of breath and a dry cough over the past 6 months. She has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for the past 40 years. Chest auscultation shows scattered expiratory wheezes in both lung fields. Spirometry shows an FEV1:FVC ratio of 65% and an FEV1 of 70% of predicted. Her diffusing capacity for carbon monoxide (DLCO) is 42% of predicted. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While patients with congestive heart failure (CHF) may present with dyspnea, they usually have additional clinical features of left-sided failure (e.g., fine crackles due to pulmonary edema, S3 gallop) or right-sided failure (e.g., peripheral pitting edema, jugular venous distention, hepatomegaly, ascites). Moreover, pulmonary edema in CHF would show features of restrictive lung disease on spirometry (normal or increased FEV1:FVC ratio).

B) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary fibrosis can cause progressive dyspnea and a dry cough but chest auscultation would typically reveal basal fine inspiratory crackles and spirometry would show features of restrictive lung disease (normal or increased FEV1:FVC ratio).

C) CORRECT:

This patient's clinical features (progressive dyspnea, dry cough, wheezes) and features of obstructive lung disease on spirometry are suggestive of emphysema, which is a clinical phenotype of COPD caused by the destruction of alveolar walls. Decreased DLCO, as seen in this patient, is a typical finding of emphysema that reflects the reduction of gas exchange due to a loss of diffusion area. The most common cause of emphysema is chronic smoking, which induces oxidative damage, inflammation, and activation of neutrophil and macrophage elastases. A less common cause is alpha-1-antitrypsin deficiency, which should be suspected in the case of early-onset emphysema or emphysema among non-smokers.

D) INCORRECT:

Bronchial asthma can cause dyspnea, a dry cough, wheeze, and features of obstructive lung disease on spirometry. However, DLCO in patients with bronchial asthma is usually normal or increased (due to increased perfusion in the lung apices) unlike in this patient with decreased DLCO. Moreover, the symptoms of asthma typically manifest as acute exacerbations unlike the progressive worsening of symptoms over 6 months here.

E) INCORRECT:

Smoking is a risk factor for developing chronic bronchitis, which is one of the clinical phenotypes of COPD. Chronic bronchitis can cause dyspnea, cough, wheezes, and features of obstructive lung disease on spirometry. However, chronic bronchitis can only be diagnosed if the patient has a productive cough on most days of 3 consecutive months in a year and this pattern of respiratory symptoms has been present for at least 2 consecutive years. Moreover, DLCO is usually not impaired by chronic bronchitis because there are no structural changes in alveoli that impair the diffusing capacity.

F) INCORRECT:

Bronchiectasis can cause dyspnea, cough, wheezes, and features of obstructive lung disease on spirometry. However, patients with bronchiectasis would have a cough productive of purulent, foul-smelling sputum, and coarse expiratory and inspiratory crackles would be present in most patients. Moreover, DLCO is typically unaffected in individuals with bronchiectasis.
questions.hint: An FEV1:FVC ratio of < 70% and a reduced FEV1  < 80% on spirometry indicate an obstructive lung pathology.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman with hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus comes to the office because of increasing shortness of breath and a dry cough over the past 6 months. She has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for the past 40 years. Chest auscultation shows scattered expiratory wheezes in both lung fields. Spirometry shows an FEV1:FVC ratio of 65% and an FEV1 of 70% of predicted. Her diffusing capacity for carbon monoxide (DLCO) is 42% of predicted. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary fibrosis can cause progressive dyspnea and a dry cough but chest auscultation would typically reveal basal fine inspiratory crackles and spirometry would show features of restrictive lung disease (normal or increased FEV1:FVC ratio).

B) CORRECT:

This patient's clinical features (progressive dyspnea, dry cough, wheezes) and features of obstructive lung disease on spirometry are suggestive of emphysema, which is a clinical phenotype of COPD caused by the destruction of alveolar walls. Decreased DLCO, as seen in this patient, is a typical finding of emphysema that reflects the reduction of gas exchange due to a loss of diffusion area. The most common cause of emphysema is chronic smoking, which induces oxidative damage, inflammation, and activation of neutrophil and macrophage elastases. A less common cause is alpha-1-antitrypsin deficiency, which should be suspected in the case of early-onset emphysema or emphysema among non-smokers.

C) INCORRECT:

Bronchial asthma can cause dyspnea, a dry cough, wheeze, and features of obstructive lung disease on spirometry. However, DLCO in patients with bronchial asthma is usually normal or increased (due to increased perfusion in the lung apices) unlike in this patient with decreased DLCO. Moreover, the symptoms of asthma typically manifest as acute exacerbations unlike the progressive worsening of symptoms over 6 months here.

D) INCORRECT:

Smoking is a risk factor for developing chronic bronchitis, which is one of the clinical phenotypes of COPD. Chronic bronchitis can cause dyspnea, cough, wheezes, and features of obstructive lung disease on spirometry. However, chronic bronchitis can only be diagnosed if the patient has a productive cough on most days of 3 consecutive months in a year and this pattern of respiratory symptoms has been present for at least 2 consecutive years. Moreover, DLCO is usually not impaired by chronic bronchitis because there are no structural changes in alveoli that impair the diffusing capacity.

E) INCORRECT:

Bronchiectasis can cause dyspnea, cough, wheezes, and features of obstructive lung disease on spirometry. However, patients with bronchiectasis would have a cough productive of purulent, foul-smelling sputum, and coarse expiratory and inspiratory crackles would be present in most patients. Moreover, DLCO is typically unaffected in individuals with bronchiectasis.
questions.hint: An FEV1:FVC ratio of < 70% and a reduced FEV1  < 80% on spirometry indicate an obstructive lung pathology.
